Award.AwardTitle: Transforming Noble Metal Nanostructure Synthesis Using Unconventional Synthetic Levers
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-Technical Abstract:
Underpinning the electronics industry is a wafer-based processing science that is able to form intricate patterns of dissimilar materials with well-defined properties and interfaces that collectively perform a useful function. One of the biggest challenges is the establishment of a corresponding processing science that integrates these wafer-based technologies with the extraordinary optical, electronic, and chemical properties derived from metallic nanoparticles. Device prototyping has, however, been stifled by an inability to define complex metal nanostructures in organized patterns where interactions are possible between adjacent structures and with the underlying wafer material. The project being carried out aims to overcome this impediment by redefining the methodologies, instrumentation, and processing science needed to define wafer-based metal nanostructures, and in doing so, provide the capabilities inaccessible through conventional methods. The research activities are being integrated with undergraduate education that involves the supervision of research internships geared toward the advancement of laboratory instrumentation by students from the College of Engineering. Outreach activities place emphasis on the matriculation of women into the engineering profession.

Technical Abstract:
The research being carried out aims to provide an understanding of the altered chemistry that arises when well-understood seed-mediated noble metal nanostructure growth modes are subjected to four unconventional synthetic levers that become accessible when seeds are immobilized on a rigid crystalline substrate. It is founded on a synthetic strategy that is able to realize periodic arrays of complex noble metal nanostructures through a three stage synthetic scheme that uses (i) a lithography-defined shadow mask to fabricate nanostructured precursors at site-specific locations, (ii) directed assembly to transform them into single crystal templates, and (iii) solution-based chemistry to further transform them into complex nanostructures. Within the scope of this strategy lies the opportunity to incorporate a new set of synthetic levers into nanostructure synthesis that fundamentally alter well-established growth modes. The project is advancing the use and understanding of four such synthetic levers: (i) a flow of reactants past an anchored substrate, (ii) synthetically-active substrate materials, (iii) substrate-imposed epitaxy, and (iv) lithographically-imposed barriers to growth. Graduate students are being trained in nanostructure synthesis and characterization, lithographic techniques, and the preparation nanostructured surfaces. This work is, hence, contributing to the grander vision that sees the extraordinary physicochemical properties of nanomaterials united with the wafer-based materials, processing techniques, and electronic devices.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit. The DMR Award aimed to understand the altered chemistry that arises in growth modes in which liquid-state chemical environments guided by unconventional synthetic levers give rise to substrate-bound noble metal nanostructures. The award has resulted in nine publications including those in high impact factor journals (2 Nano Letters, IF 11.23; ACS Catalysis, IF 12.35; ACS Applied Materials and Interfaces, IF 8.76; Nanoscale, IF, 6.90) as well as a comprehensive review article on synthesis, assembly, and application of substrate-immobilized noble metal nanoplates (Journal of Materials Chemistry C, IF 7.06). The PI and her research team have disseminated this research through six oral presentations, four of which were invited (MRS, E−MRS, and University of Cagliari) with three other invited talks being cancelled due to COVID-19. Specific research accomplishments include: (i) a plasmon-mediated synthesis giving rise to periodic arrays of gold nanoplates from substrate-based seeds lined with planar defects, (ii) a first-of-its-kind synthesis in which three sequentially applied symmetry-breaking events are used to define chiral gold nanostructures with spiral geometries at predefined locations on a substrate surface, (iii) the utilization of a self-regulating ligand-exchange process as a time-resolved chemical control in a nanostructure synthesis where one capping agent is gradually consumed and slowly replaced by second agent demonstrating profoundly different properties, (iv) a solution-based growth mode in which the optical excitation of electron–hole pairs within ZnO tetrapods lead to its surface being decorated with noble metal nanostructures, and (v) providing a resolution to long-standing controversies regarding the role of nanostructure capping ligands in the catalytic reduction of 4-nitrophenol.

Broader Impacts. The colloidal synthesis of plasmonic nanostructures has been greatly enriched by protocols that utilize the internal defect structure within seeds to guide syntheses along growth pathways that are otherwise unachievable. The research carried out under this DMR award brings this same capability to syntheses carried out at a liquid-substrate interface. In doing so, it significantly expands the breadth of nanostructure architectures accessible to the substrate platform, capabilities that are of relevance to the multidisciplinary audience working toward functionalizing such structures for chemical and biological detection as well as their integration with optical and scanning microscopy probes, electronic circuitry, biopatterns, microfluidics, and lab-on-a-chip platforms. The PI has also had an impact as an organizer for a symposium at 257th ACS Spring Meeting entitled Surface Chemistry of Colloidal Nanocrystals and the lead organizer for the Spring 2021 Materials Research Society (MRS) virtual symposium entitled Molecular and Colloidal Plasmonics – Synthesis and Applications. Highlights in terms of student training, mentorship, and graduate student achievement include: (i) three undergraduate research internships, (ii) a co-authorship by undergraduate Yuko Inoue, (iii) a first place prize to Trevor Demille for his poster presentation at the 6th Annual Midwest Imaging and Microanalysis Workshop, (iv) Spencer Golze as the recipient of the Notre Dame Integrated Imaging Facility Award for the Best Electron Beam Imaging Publication in 2019, and (v) mentor for the Advancing Women Leaders and Building Bridges Mentoring Programs. Community engagement and outreach successes include: (i) the mentorship and judging of high school science fair projects, (ii) twice hosting a five hour per week, two semester research internship for high school student Alicia Katzelis, (iii) participation in the annual Science Alive event, and (ii) participation in the Classical Conversations Science Fair. Yuko Inoue and Alicia Katzelis, having since graduated, are now both alumni of this award. Yuko is working towards a Ph.D. at Notre Dame and Alicia is a freshman at Purdue University pursuing a degree in Pharmaceutical Science.
